Hip, once again, I wonder if I actually need to clarify anything with you having already been so ON THE SPOT! But I'll try to be more specific because the guy seems to not know even the basics, so it may help him.

OK, Rooky2k, let me try to enlighten you in reference to what we commonly refer to as CAP.

Reaching a CAP, when we talk about NWN, means reaching the maximum possible MAGICAL ENHANCEMENT of that particular base score. That applies to EVERYTHING in this game, but each different type of character feature has a different cap. Here is a rough list:

- Ability scores: The cap for an ability score is +12 (+6 modifier, because you gain +1 modifier for every two additional points in any particular stat: 8 and 9 give -1 modifier, 10 and 11 give a 0 modifier, 12 and 13 give a +1 modifier, so on and so forth). When we talk about capped Wisdom in this build, for example, we mean the BASE score of 20 (+5 Modifier) enhanced magically through buffs and items to 32 (+11 modifier). It won't go beyond that. Multiple sources of this type of enhancement stack with one another, except for two identical spells (you shouldn't cast 2 owl's wisdom on yourself, as only the highest roll will work). But all different items that give you Wisdom will stack with one another, so a Periapt of Wisdom +3 and a Ring of Wisdom +5 will add +8 to your Wisdom score. If you cast an Owl's Wisdom spell on top of it all, you can reach the cap by rolling a 3 (the computer does the rolls automatically, so all you can do is keep your fingers crossed).

- AB and AC: The cap for AB and AC is +20. AB is simple, as there is only one type of AB enhancement, although there are other enhancements that influence AB indirectly (like capping the combat stat, in this case DEX, which won't count towards the +20 cap). AB enhancements stack with one another, so GMW and Divine Favor will give +5 each to AB enhancement for a total of +10. If you add Divine Power, in this build it will give +5 to AB as well, so GMW + Divine Favor + Divine Power = +15 AB enhancement, so on and so forth.

However, AC has 5 different types of modifiers, each of them with a +20 cap:

Natural AC
Deflection AC
Armor AC
Shield AC
Dodge AC

None of the above, except for dodge, stack with themselves. So if you have a Ring of Protection +3 (+3 Deflection AC) and a Cloak of Protection +4 (+4 Deflection AC), it's the same as if you had only the cloak, only the highest value counts. Boots of Dodging and, say Divine Shield and Haste (both of which give Dodge AC), will stack to a maximum of +20. So the only way to cap your Deflection AC is to find a Cloak of Protection +20, and the same goes for all the other modifiers except Dodge AC. To cap Dodge AC, all you need to do is find several items / buffs that give you Dodge AC bonuses up to +20.

- Skills: The cap for skill enhancements is +50. This only includes MAGICAL enhancements, so feats like Alertness, Skill Focus and such DON'T COUNT TOWARDS THE CAP.

I hope things are a bit clearer now. I know how painful it can be to be a member of the ECB whilst still being a noob, but don't worry, with that kind of attitude and curiosity, you're going to grow into a better player. I wish I could say soon, but this game is so complex that it'll probably take some time. Keep it up, though, don't give up!

This is a single-hand build.  A DWer would need either fighter or CoT levels to fit all the feats in. This is pretty much a stealth build with SD cheese minus the sneak attacks.  You can use a shield but then will lose the monk AC, WIS AC and monk move speed.  Your decision.  Robes are essential.

Don't know what you mean by "rotation".  This is a self-buffer so your first priority are all the AB and damage boosts like Bless, Aid, Div Favor, Darkfire, GMW, Prayer, Battletide plus Div Power to exploit the free attack.  Next priority comes your ability boosts like Bull STR, Cat DEX, Endurance.  Next, all your defensive buffs like Death Ward, Magic Vest, Neg NRG Protect.  After slotting all buffs, and if you have any spare slots, HotG & WoF are handy vs. mobs.  Flamestrike is a good slot if there is room.
Is this build on for newbie?
 
If you are comfortable with exhaustive self-buffing, it's fine for a player of any flavour. 
Any advice?
I recommend a few changes.  Domain:  I'd swap Plant out for either War or Animal.  DEX is the primary AB ability so you need to buff that one and only a domain will enable Cat's Grace.  Barkskin is handy but there are pots arounb so the difference in AC is not significant and Creeping Doom is very tough to use when you have hirelings or other party wandering around the combat zone. They will die in the cloud of gnats, usually before the enemy does. 

As handy as Called Shots are, the build's feat starvation precludes that choice because Empower Spell is an essential metamagic feat for self-buffing optimization and you'll need to fit it in at Level 9. 

At Level 27, swapping monk 7 for SD 2 gets you Uncanny Dodge at least.  Max isn't dumping to discipline with monk so all the skills (detection, stealth, tumble) should work out the same. Monk 7 gains nothing worth striving for.

I am assuming you will be playing this build through HotU as well.  Epic Dodge will not be available.  On this build, ED has been designed for a 40-cap server where players play their completed toons for extended periods for high-level questing.

Usually, to find a plug 'n play type build for SoU-HotU, you should examine those optimized for Level 30.  Even in that case, the last 2 levels will never be realized because HotU ends at Level 28, SoU around 12-14 ish.  Unfortunately, most of our ECB mid-epic have been optimized for the Arelith server ATM. They could be considered but better optimized without those restrictive level-up rules and potential for XP penalties.  There are also some mid-epic in the legacy archive you might like.

Hopefully, all my deliberation fits into the category of "Advice" rather than "Confusion" and ends up making your decision easier. Life is a dice roll

Another very good class combination I recognise!

If I'm just starting out on a server for the very first time, this is the build I use to scout things out. It can use both ranged and melee attacks for its whole progression, can get HIPS as early as level 8,, and requires very little gear to operate effectively thanks to all the cleric buffs. Travel/Trickery is a good domain combo if perma-haste items are rare or non-existent.

I usually go Cleric 6 to start, staying at range and hiding behind summons or party members. Scale mail + heavy crossbow or mace +  dire badger through to Skeleton warrior works well. Web also works well if you have travel domain.

After that, monk for 7 (stealth, tumble, switch to Kama and monk stuff) and SD for 8. Makes the progression a little more combat heavy in the early stages than this particular version as it gets less cleric before 20 [monk 4 cleric 12 sd 4 pre epic], and staggers the feats back a bit trying to fit in Dodge and Mobility early. That said, HIPS at level 8 is a great get-out-of-jail free card if you wander into a sticky situation.

I also usually opt for duel wielding kamas (ambi + twf + itwf instead of 2 Dex and cs) so that if backed into a corner, I can pull out the old switch-the-offhand-weapon-on-the-quickbar-back-and-forth attacks per round exploit. Not often, but occasionally.  

A very powerful combo all round: plenty of options up its sleeve. My recommended first play-through build in any new environment!

posts.author: Maximillian_Kane
posts.content:
Also, since we're reviving this topic, let me say something about domains. The way I see it, there are 5 domains that work well with this build:

1- Trickery - This gives you access to Improved Invisibility, which means 50% concealment bonus to stack with your Epic Dodge and make you virtually unhittable by anything that's not an AA.

2- War - War domain gives you Cat's Grace as a level 2 spell, which Clerics otherwise don't have, and Aura of Vitality, which if cast after Divine Power, will cap your Strength at 20 (if you go Halfling or Gnome this doesn't apply).

3- Travel - In worlds where you don't have access to permanent Haste items, this domain is IMO a must. You get +4 Dodge AC and + 1 attack per round with Haste. It makes spellbook management a bit complicated, but the rewards are well worth it.

4- Plant - With the Plant domain, you get access to Bakskin, which allows you to save the amulet slot for Wisdom-enhancing items in servers where that's the only slot you can use to enhance Wisdom. The build is supposed to be generic, and in Vanilla NWN, there are only Wisdom-enhancing Amulets, no rings, cloaks, etc, hence my choice to post this build with this domain. However, this becomes very droppable if your server has a variety of items that allow you to boost Wisdom in various slots.

5- Animal: Animal also has Cat's Grace as a spell, although in an ideal world with no restrictions, I see no reason to pick this over War. However, on WoG there's a Pantheon system that severely restricts the domains one can pick for their characters, and one of the good God choices for this build is Ehlonna, which forces you to take Plant and Animal domains. So, I thought I'd list this just in case to help you circumvent any restrictions your server might have and pick domains that make sense for this build.

Now, this is where meta-knowledge of the server helps you select the best domains for your toon. I would suggest that, even though this guy is a POWERHOUSE, he shouldn't be your first build in the server, as you won't know how to optimize the domain picks, not knowing what's available to him. Start with something like my Champion of the Wilderness (a totally self-sufficient build that can go from 1-40 almost naked), learn the server, then make this guy and select the domains based on what items you know to be available.

I think this is it for domains. If I remember anything else, I'll edit this post later.

Cheers!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
It  can be hard to defend against a swarm of IKD spammers.
Immunity items (often on boots) is a great option against knockdowns in general, but you also want items with other properties, eg haste, AC or dexterity.

A high discipline does the job as long as it beats the AB of the attacker. It also helps against other combat moves.

Not being hit is another option. A very high AC helps against most things, but not against enemies with high enough AB and not against natural 20 attack rolls.
This dexer gets a high AC from monk bonus, dex bonus, wis bonus, and cleric spells. Uncanny dodge helps retain the dex AC bonus.
It combines this with 50% concealment from Improved invisibility.
Epic dodge causes a character to automatically avoid the first successful attack or the first (possibly unsuccessful) attack of opportunity or riposte in a round, not simply the first attack in a round. (From NwNWiki)
The combination of a high AC, 50% concealment and ED helps avoid a lot of hits, also from natural 20 attack rolls. It also makes it very hard to land critical hits against you.
Against a swarm of enemies, you risk more natural 20 hits per round, so some of them may actually land their attack.

This is also a good opportunity to discuss something very important: RESTING ITEMS x ADVENTURING ITEMS. For this build it isn't as relevant, but for others, it will make a HUGE DIFFERENCE. When you play a caster, especially a spellsword, there's often a lot of switching going on between items. For example, if you cast Owl's Wisdom on yourself, then unequip those boots, you won't lose any bonus you have, because the wisdom lost will remain there as a buff.

You should also memorize all your long-term buffs and some long-term summoning spells (i.e. Extended Create Greater Undead at level 9), on the last slots (the farthest ones to the right), and cast them before switching gear, especially if you plan to switch gear that will make you lose Wisdom as a result, which will cause you to lose spell slots as well. Once they're cast, you won't lose anything from swapping items. And these undeads can help you bait a few dispels off your enemies.

As I said, for this build it's not so relevant, because WIS also adds to AC, and so you shouldn't be eager to lose any of your WIS, but for Myth's Blood & Faith, for example, once that capped WIS has given you the extra spell slots, it doesn't do anything extra for you, so you can easily swap your items around for more combat-orientend ones.

posts.content: True Seeing does nothing vs concealed enemies. If an enemy has Improved Invisibility/SCV/Empty Body, Blind Fight alone gives you +50% damage (more than the full 2WF feats, in most cases). Whether Improved Critical is good or not, and whether it is better than having 2 more attacks, depends entirely on what you are going to fight. I haven't done any math, but in most cases I think I'd go with what Max did here.

Although this could work, one of the most amazing things about this build is the survivability, with Epic Dodge and a very high AC. This proposed tweak might work in high magic worlds, where another weapon would add more DPS, but it causes you to lose 2 AB points and 1 AC for what seems to be more damage at first glance. However, having more attacks per round that don't hit won't add ANY damage at all to your character, and may in fact REDUCE your damage output if it causes you to miss more. So, mostly, you'd do more damage against enemies that you can already hit anyway, while doing LESS damage to enemies with higher ACs. which in my experience are generally tougher. That's why I chose to forgo the TWF feats.
